headline: Obama jabs that Trump is ‘jealous of Covid’s media coverage.’
text: Former President Obama, delivering a withering speech in Orlando on behalf of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday, hammered President Trump for complaining about how much attention the coronavirus has been getting, joking that his successor “is jealous of Covid’s media coverage.”

headline: A Princess, Long Denied by Belgium’s Former King, Meets With Her Father
text: For years, Delphine Boël, an artist, fought to be recognized as the daughter of the former Belgian monarch, King Albert II.

headline: Some Covid Survivors Have Antibodies That Attack the Body, not Virus
text: Some survivors of Covid-19 carry worrying signs that their immune system has turned on the body, reminiscent of potentially debilitating diseases like lupus and rheumatoid arthritis, a new study has found.

headline: As Election Nears, Trump Makes a Final Push Against Climate Science
text: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has recently removed the chief scientist at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the nation’s premier scientific agency, installed new political staff who have questioned accepted facts about climate change and imposed stricter controls on communications at the agency.

headline: Review: Calvin Royal III and Dormeshia Glow at Fall for Dance
text: The crowds at New York City Center’s Fall for Dance festival don’t applaud politely; they roar. So what happens in the absence of a live audience? In this case, at least, it creates a space to shine a brighter light on the poetics of dance.

headline: How New York’s Small Cinemas Are Hanging On
text: Hollywood bromances, gay skin flicks, obscure art-house hits — Nick Nicolaou has screened them all at the assorted New York City movie theaters he has owned in the last 38 years.

headline: Roots of War: When Armenia Talked Tough, Azerbaijan Took Action
text: TERTER, Azerbaijan — For years, the leaders of Azerbaijan and Armenia had agreed to postpone discussion about the status of the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, to avoid inflaming passions. But that changed suddenly this spring, when Armenia’s populist prime minister declared the area indisputably Armenian.

headline: Le Crocodile in the Wythe Hotel Opens for Private Dining
text: The creative lengths to which restaurateurs and chefs in New York and elsewhere are going to compensate for pandemic hardships are dazzling. And often effective. Take Jake Leiber and Aidan O’Neal at Le Crocodile, the brasserie at the Wythe Hotel in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They have turned the rooms on the hotel’s second floor into four — soon to be eight — elegant private dining spaces, each accommodating a single party (rooms can hold four to six guests, or eight to 10). A $100-per-person menu has a raft of choices, and a uniform menu is not required. A dozen seasonal appetizers, like venison tartare, mushroom pâté and onion soup, can be followed by main courses that include vegetarian options, like a chanterelle omelet and a squash tagine. A similar pivot to private parties is happening at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill and Blue Hill at Stone Barns establishments. Mr. Barber’s Manhattan restaurant can be booked by a single party, and the dining room and other spaces at the Westchester property, like the bar, are also available for single-party booking ($195 and up per person, plus a room fee of $500 to $2,500).

headline: ‘Presidential Malpractice’ Over Covid-19
text: To the Editor:

headline: Why Leftists Should Vote for Biden in Droves
text: If you were to think up a nightmare for the socialist left, it would be hard to think of someone more horrifying than President Trump: an authoritarian billionaire who uses the White House to enrich himself and his inner circle while deploying racism to cleave the working class and shunning international cooperation.

headline: Pushing Deep Into G.O.P. Turf, Democrats Are Poised to Expand House Majority
text: VERONA, N.Y. — Pushing further into Republican territory one week before Election Day, Democrats are poised to expand their majority in the House while Republicans, weighed down by President Trump’s low standing in crucial battlegrounds, are scrambling to offset losses.

headline: Muslim Countries Denounce French Response to Killing of Teacher, Urge Boycott
text: BRUSSELS — Since a young Muslim beheaded a French schoolteacher who had shown caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in a class, France has conducted dozens of raids against suspected Islamic extremists, closed a major mosque and shut down some Muslim aid groups.

headline: What Happens When Sarah Cooper Speaks in Her Own Voice?
text: Was Donald Trump good for comedy? The comic Lewis Black recently answered this persistent question with an understandable tone of exhaustion, saying the president is “good for comedy in the way a stroke is good for a nap.”

headline: To combat the virus, some schools have moved classes outside.
text: First graders sit crisscross applesauce on tree stumps, hands sky-high to ask a question. Third graders peer closely at the plants growing in class gardens, or spread themselves out in a sunflower-filled space to read. When the sun beats down, students take shelter under shades made from boat sails.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Do I Always Tilt My Head Like That?’
text: When I lifted the baby girl to my chest, it was love, overwhelming and instant. Then came the Spider-Man light-up shoes. The short haircut. The six-pack of superhero undies from the boys section. The tantrums over having to wear a top at the pool. The revelation that a different life was possible. The trying of new names. The telling of family, friends, school. And now our love is different, new. The love of mother and her 8-year-old son. The loving of someone for who they truly are, not whom you had imagined them to be. — Kate Streip

headline: One Last Time, With Feeling: VOTE.
text: As this ulcer-inducing election enters the homestretch, early turnout numbers are breaking records. Tens of millions of Americans have already mailed in or dropped off their ballots or stood in lines to vote early.

headline: What Happened to Your American Dream?
text: When and how did your “American dream” die? This is the question the artist Lizania Cruz puts to readers of her project “Obituaries of the American Dream,” commissioned by El Museo del Barrio in New York to feature in its first national survey of contemporary work by Latinx artists. The project defines the “American dream” as “the ideal that all individuals can achieve upward mobility based on their hard work” and invites the public to share their experiences, which she posts daily on the project’s website.

headline: Obama Campaigns for Biden, Slams Trumps Handling of Pandemic
text: Former President Barack Obama delivered remarks in Orlando, Fla., on behalf of Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday, and criticized how the White House has handled the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: Can We Trust Pennsylvania’s Polls?
text: BENSALEM, Pa. — Two men, one in a Ford F-150 truck bedecked with Trump decals and the other in a Chevrolet Malibu, were stopped at a traffic light, arguing about politics. The light turned green, the truck pulled into a parking lot and the Chevy followed. The man in the truck jumped out, brandishing a trailer hitch head like a war hammer.

headline: Trump Appointee Rescinds Rule Shielding Government News Outlets From Federal Tampering
text: WASHINGTON — The chief of the U.S. Agency for Global Media on Monday rescinded a rule that protects news outlets funded by the government, including Voice of America, from federal tampering.

headline: Turkey Sentences U.S. Consulate Employee to Over 5 Years in Jail
text: A Turkish court on Tuesday sentenced a Turkish employee of the American Consulate in Istanbul to more than five years in jail after finding that he had knowingly aided a terrorist group.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing
text: The Russian government on Tuesday made its boldest move yet to try to stem a second wave of coronavirus infections, mandating masks in public places throughout the country.

headline: Are masks still required in Louisiana? Lawmakers say no. The governor says yes, and sues.
text: Louisiana’s statewide mask mandate and other coronavirus restrictions were up in the air on Tuesday, after Republican legislators used an obscure clause in state law to suspend the public health emergency declared by the governor.

headline: Sanders and Warren Accuse N.Y. Democrats of False Advertising
text: ALBANY, N.Y. — Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren entered an unexpected clash on Tuesday with New York Democratic leaders over the fate of a progressive third party.

headline: Vintage Alfa Romeos to Be Auctioned at Sotheby’s
text: Arguably among the most flamboyant designs in automotive history, Alfa Romeo’s three B.A.T. cars — for Berlina Aerodinamica Tecnica — are to be auctioned at Sotheby’s in New York City on Wednesday. Presented at the auction house’s Contemporary Art evening sale and expected to bring a hammer price of between $14 million and $20 million, the dazzling threesome is being publicly offered for the first time as a united group.

headline: Most Americans have been wearing masks since spring, the C.D.C. says.

headline: Britain’s Health Workers Face 2nd Virus Wave, but This Time With Less Support
text: LONDON — The weekly clapping in support of health workers by Britons during the first part of the pandemic has petered out. The government has mostly stopped asking people to stay home and avoid the virus to keep the National Health Service from being overwhelmed. Campaigns to feed and house exhausted health workers have dwindled.

headline: Why You Shouldn’t Worry About Studies Showing Waning Coronavirus Antibodies
text: The portion of people in Britain with detectable antibodies to the coronavirus fell by roughly 27 percent over a period of three months this summer, researchers reported Monday, prompting fears that immunity to the virus is short-lived.

headline: Sharon Hunt, Teacher for a Quarter-Century, Dies at 65
text: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

headline: Robert Murray, Coal Baron With Clout, Dies at 80

headline: California Tax Revolt Faces a Retreat, 40 Years Later

The law has been considered sacrosanct ever since, something California governors and legislators challenge at their peril.

headline: Trump Allies Amp Up Fight Over Tech’s Legal Shield Before Election

text: President Trump lashed out at Michigan’s governor, Gretchen Whitmer, during his rally in Lansing, Mich. Tuesday criticizing her for imposing too many restrictions to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

Barcelona, announced Tuesday that he had resigned, bringing an abrupt end to a tenure in which he had taken power almost by accident, nearly driven away the best player in the club’s history and provoked a recall effort that many expected to lead to his ouster as soon as next month.

headline: The Other Rookie Star of the World Series? Globe Life Field

headline: How Mitch McConnell Delivered Justice Amy Coney Barrett’s Rapid Confirmation
text: WASHINGTON — Within hours of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death last month, Senator Mitch McConnell was on the phone with President Trump, assuring him that Senate Republicans would not hesitate to fill the sudden vacancy despite the imminent election.

headline: I Approve This Message. Now, Remember Your Secrecy Envelope.
text: Welcome to On Politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for coverage of all things media and messaging. I’m writing from Philadelphia, where I’ve moved for the rest of the race and have subsisted largely on the true Philadelphia sandwich: the roast pork, provolone and broccoli rabe!

headline: Hospitals Are Reeling Under a 46 Percent Spike in Covid-19 Patients
text: MILWAUKEE — The patient who died on Tuesday morning at Aurora St. Luke’s Medical Center was rolled out of her room under a white sheet. One nurse, fighting back tears, stood silently in the hall as the outline of the body passed by — one more death in an eight-month-old pandemic that has no end in sight.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: The pandemic in the United States is reaching fearsome new levels, as the country’s seven-day average for new cases exceeded 70,000 for the first time and more than 26 states are reporting case numbers at or near record levels.

headline: Californians, Vote Yes on Prop 16
text: Black and Latino people have been hit hardest by America’s recent one-two punch of public health and economic crises. They’ve been hospitalized for Covid-19 at quadruple the rate of white Americans. Their businesses have struggled to get the support they requested from the government’s Paycheck Protection Program. As of August, the unemployment rate for African-Americans was nearly double that of white Americans.

headline: When My President Sang ‘Amazing Grace’
text: This is my last regular column before Election Day, so what is there left to say? Instead of giving you an answer, let me leave you with a question, which I think is the question. What would you do if your kid came home from school and said:

headline: Trump Campaign Website Is Defaced by Hackers
text: President Trump’s campaign website was briefly taken over by hackers who defaced the site on Tuesday.

headline: Kavanaugh’s Opinion in Wisconsin Voting Case Raises Alarms Among Democrats

headline: Thieves Steal 6 Million Medical Gloves From Florida Supplier

headline: Qatar Expresses ‘Regrets’ but Defends Invasive Exams of Women on 10 Flights
text: The government of Qatar on Wednesday expressed “regrets,” but defended a decision to pull more than a dozen women from a Qatar Airways flight in Doha and subject them to invasive medical exams after an abandoned newborn was found in an airport bathroom.

headline: ‘The Craft: Legacy’ Review: More Dull Carbon Copy Than Cult Classic
text: The long-awaited follow-up to the 1996 cult classic “The Craft” recalls its iconic predecessor in many ways. Just like before, a newcomer at a high school completes a foursome of teen girls who learn to harness their witchy powers. It hasn’t lost the levitation game “light as a feather,” the ominous snakes or the famous line; “We’re the weirdos, mister,” though it’s recontextualized for a climactic moment. When the new girl, Lily (Cailee Spaeny), and her mom (Michelle Monaghan) sing along to Alanis Morissette’s “Hand in My Pocket,” the needle drop will make you wonder if this version takes place in the mid-’90s too.

headline: Philadelphia Protests Continue After Fatal Shooting by Police
text: PHILADELPHIA — Protesters looted stores and scuffled with police late Tuesday in a second night of street protests over the fatal police shooting of Walter Wallace Jr., a 27-year-old Black man, during a confrontation more than 24 hours earlier.

headline: Dodgers’ Justin Turner Was Pulled From Game 6 After Positive Virus Test

But this year, concerned about mail delays in the pandemic, he took his completed ballot to the post office in Cologne the same day he received it on Sept. 16.

headline: Morale sags among British health workers, and other news from around the world.
text: As Britain is hit by a second wave of coronavirus infections and deaths, the country’s doctors and nurses are bracing for what is expected to be a deluge of new patients over the next six months. But this time, they say, the wave is coming without the same sense of caution among a coronavirus-weary public, nor with a clear government strategy to contain the virus and address rapidly filling intensive care units.

headline: The Lockdown That Felt Like It Might Last Forever Has Finally Ended

headline: Trump Couldn’t Play the Tough Guy This Time
text: The presidential debate on Thursday between Donald Trump and Joe Biden featured a glaring absence: Neither candidate mentioned Mosul. In their final showdown four years ago, Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton name-checked that Iraqi city — from which the United States had recently helped expel the Islamic State — a whopping 23 times.

headline: How to Build an Intentional Community
text: “You need a dream,” says Shirley Meredeen, 90, a founding member of the Older Women’s Co-Housing Project, a group of 26 women over 50 who live together in North London. In 1998, Meredeen and a friend, both 68 and living alone, went to a presentation about co-housing, an outgrowth from the communes of the 1960s, which started in Denmark among private households clustered around shared spaces. Afterward, Meredeen and her friend imagined a place where women could age together and not end up in a nursing home, alone, “dribbling in the corner,” Meredeen says. “We wanted to be in charge of our own lives as we got older.”

headline: Looking Back on Baseball’s Silent Season
text: Two words that have been on my mind constantly these recent months are “room tone.” Room tone is the sound a space makes when there is no other sound but the sound of the space itself. The subtle sounds in a high-ceilinged room with brick walls and wide windows are different from those of a small room with wood-paneled walls and narrow windows, or those of the upper deck of a completely empty stadium, or those of the lower deck of a completely empty stadium.

headline: She Had a Headache for Months. Then She Could Barely See.
text: The 61-year-old woman put on her reading glasses to try to decipher the tiny black squiggles on the back of the package of instant pudding. Was it two cups of milk? Or three? The glasses didn’t seem to help. The fuzzy, faded marks refused to become letters. The right side of her head throbbed — as it had for weeks. The constant aggravation of the headache made everything harder, and it certainly wasn’t helping her read this label. She rubbed her forehead, then brought her hand down to cover her right eye. The box disappeared into darkness. She could see only the upper-left corner of the instructions. Everything else was black. She quickly moved her hand to cover her left eye. The tiny letters sprang into focus.

headline: Arrested, Tortured, Imprisoned: The U.S. Contractors Abandoned in Kuwait
text: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Cookbooks Help Me Escape These Days
text: Years before I ever stepped foot in Rome or the Chianti Valley, I traveled there by reading cookbooks. I pored through Ada Boni’s “Italian Regional Cooking,” committing pictures to memory so that one day I might, say, set up my own wood-fired rotisserie and prepare three different types of fowl at once, too. I learned from the photos in midcentury cookbooks how fresh anchovies and piles of sunbaked sea salt are harvested in Sicily. When I read “Honey From a Weed,” I sopped up the flavors of Patience Gray’s tales of cooking off the land while chasing marble across the Mediterranean with her sculptor beau. From a handful of single-subject books I still treasure, I spent hours learning about the regional differences in pasta sauces and the individual histories of dozens, if not hundreds, of pasta shapes I hoped to one day taste. I grew to love the hot-blooded, tradition-protecting Italian culinary sensibility I got to know through these books — so much so that I learned the language and eventually moved to the country.

headline: Trump’s Presidency Smashed the ‘Decency Floor’
text: Until four years ago, there was what you might call a Floor of Decency. This was the basic minimum standard of behavior to be an accepted member of society. Even when people did bad things, they at least tried to pretend that they were good, that they operated according to the basic values of society. You may or may not like the people in, say, the Obama or Bush administrations, you may think they made grave mistakes, but you have to admit they generally strove to meet this basic minimum.

headline: Kicked From the Curb in Alabama
text: Last week, the Supreme Court acquiesced to another attack on the voting rights of all Americans. In a 5-3 decision, the court blocked a trial judge’s ruling permitting Alabama counties to offer curbside voting as a reasonable accommodation to disabled voters.

Runners registered for these races, including me, must now decide whether we feel comfortable racing in-person and, if so, how we can best protect ourselves and the runners loping past us (or, for the speedy, vice versa).

headline: The Supreme Court Should Not Muck Around in State Election Laws

headline: Democrats target the true silent majority in Georgia: people who don’t vote.
text: Over 100 million eligible, voting-age Americans did not vote in 2016, more than the number who voted for either presidential candidate. In Georgia, about 60 percent of eligible voters cast a ballot in that year’s presidential race, roughly on par with the national figure of 55 percent.

headline: Americans voting from abroad worry their mail-in ballots won’t arrive on time.
text: Americans living outside the United States have been making plans to vote in the general election since the summer. But amid the coronavirus pandemic and global mail disruptions, their ballots still may not arrive in time to be counted on Nov. 3. And recent Supreme Court decisions mean that late arrivals in some states will not be counted at all.

headline: The Hardest Fight to Have With Your Teen
text: I have long thought that when it comes to being a parent in the pandemic, it might be the hardest for parents of teenagers. Parents of little ones can meet most of our children’s social needs, and our kids still kind of want to be around us. Not so for parents of teens. I recall with poignant shame what a complete nightmare I was at 16 when I was told, for various sensible reasons, that I could not hang out with my idiot friends. I can only imagine the epic battles that would have ensued had there been a pandemic raging, keeping me from hotboxed station wagons.

headline: The Fight Over Voting
text: Democrats and Republicans are engaged in a furious struggle over voting rights. In almost every instance, Democrats are trying to make it easier for Americans to cast ballots, and Republicans are trying to make it harder.

headline: Facebook, Google and Twitter C.E.O.s return to Washington to defend their content moderation.
text: For more than two decades, internet companies have been shielded from liability for much of what their users post by a once-obscure rule called Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act. Now that shield — and how internet companies moderate content on their sites — is being questioned by lawmakers on both sides of the political aisle.

headline: Republicans and Democrats have similar goals. They will make different arguments.
text: If there is one thing Republicans and Democrats can agree on, it’s that the internet giants have become too powerful and need to be restrained. Many lawmakers also agree that the companies should be stripped of a law that shields websites from liability for content created by their users.

headline: Reclaiming, on Netflix, an Ancient Battle Beloved of Germany’s Far Right

The historical epic — reminiscent of the long-running History channel series “Vikings” — centers on a tribe of villagers in the first century A.D. trying to survive in a forested region of what is now northern Germany. Its rugged protagonists clash violently with rival tribes and, most of all, with the Roman forces who control the area.

headline: Gun Rooms Turned Bedrooms off the English Coast

headline: House Hunting in England: A Refurbished Army Fortress in the English Channel
text: This circular man-made island, known as Spitbank Fort, sits about a half-mile off the southern coast of England in the Solent, a narrow waterway feeding the English Channel. One of three similar islands built by the British military during the 1860s and ’70s, the refurbished fortress has 33,000 square feet of living space covering three floors, with 12 bedrooms, two kitchens, a pool, a central courtyard and multiple leisure, event and dining areas.

headline: 10 Classical Concerts to Stream in November
text: With many opera houses and concert halls still closed by the coronavirus pandemic for months to come, the musical action has moved online. That’s been the case since March, of course — but as the weather cools and outdoor presentations grow more difficult, artists and institutions are creating digital presentations with more care and intention.

headline: The San Francisco Symphony Plunges Into a New World
text: Esa-Pekka Salonen didn’t expect to make his entrance at the San Francisco Symphony with a virtual premiere.

headline: As Climate Disasters Pile Up, a Radical Proposal Gains Traction
text: WASHINGTON — As the effects of climate change become more devastating, prominent research institutions and government agencies are focusing new money and attention on an idea once dismissed as science fiction: Artificially cooling the planet, in the hopes of buying humanity more time to cut greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Michelangelo Pistoletto Endures. Even Covid Couldn’t Stop Him.
text: For someone who is 87 and who survived a severe bout of Covid-19 that put him in the hospital for a month, the Italian artist Michelangelo Pistoletto was steadily upbeat on the phone, speaking from a respite on the Ligurian coast.

headline: He Helped Create Lollapalooza. Now He Wants to Save Live Music.
text: For small music venues, the situation is dire. Starved for revenue since March, and with no lifeline from Congress, independent clubs across the country are shuttering by the dozen — devastating fans and artists alike and delivering a brutal blow to the ecosystem that develops tomorrow’s Grammy winners and underground heroes.

headline: How Musk Oxen Make It Through Arctic Nights and Never-Ending Days
text: In the distant reaches of northeastern Greenland, musk oxen amble across the tundra, grazing as they go. As Arctic creatures, they need to gather enough energy to make it through cold, dark winters. So when the bright summers come, they eat as if their lives depend on it — as in fact they do.

headline: Your New Favorite Sauce
text: Yotam Ottolenghi brought us a smart new recipe this week for a giant couscous cake with roasted pepper sauce (above). What’s great about it is, you can use that amazing sauce on anything you like. You could spoon it on pan-fried tofu, Yotam wrote, or pair it with leftover meatballs. You could eat it with eggs in the morning, or with a cheese sandwich at lunch.

headline: Mark Morris Dance Group Celebrates Its 40th Anniversary Online
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group will celebrate its 40th anniversary with a digital season, its first since the coronavirus shutdown. Not that the company has been absent from the digital world. In May, it released four new dances by Mr. Morris, the company’s artistic director, made using Zoom, and has been streaming archival material.

headline: ‘I can never do enough’: I.C.U. workers record their anguish as the coronavirus surges.
text: A journal that sits in a staff room just off the intensive care unit at a Milwaukee hospital tells the story of the devastating surge of the coronavirus that much of the country is experiencing. In longhand, the nurses and doctors who are tending to desperately ill Covid-19 patients share their thoughts in the journal, as a way to help one another through this.

headline: Several people went to hospitals after a Trump rally in Omaha where hundreds were stranded in the cold.
text: OMAHA —  After hundreds of people who attended a Trump rally in Omaha Tuesday night were left stranded on an airport tarmac for hours in near-freezing temperatures, at least six people were taken to a hospital and about two dozen others sought medical attention, according to local authorities, rally attendees and reports from journalists at the scene.

headline: As Supreme Court Weighs Election Cases, a New Life for Bush v. Gore
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision in Bush v. Gore 20 years ago was supposed to work like the tape recorder in “Mission: Impossible.” It was meant to produce a president and then self-destruct.

headline: Social Security Seemed Like a Future Problem. The Virus Changed That.
text: Social Security has always seemed like a future problem, with experts long predicting a benefits squeeze in the decades ahead. But the coronavirus has put tens of millions of Americans out of work, and economists are predicting that the recovery will take years.

headline: The election’s big twist: the racial gap between Republicans and Democrats is shrinking.
text: American politicians have often sought to exploit the nation’s racial and ethnic divides for political gain. During the Trump era, voters are not responding as expected.

headline: The Issue That Might Sink the Brexit Trade Talks: Fishing
text: LONDON — In the greater scheme of things, fishing is a tiny industry. Just 12,000 people in Britain fish from 6,000 vessels, contributing less than half of one percent of gross domestic product — less than the upmarket London department store Harrods, according to one analysis. The same holds true for most continental European nations.

headline: ‘City Hall’ Review: Frederick Wiseman, for the People
text: For more than a half-century, Frederick Wiseman has been telling the story of the United States, one documentary and fluorescent-lit room at a time. Since directing his first film, “Titicut Follies” (1967), about a Massachusetts prison for the criminally insane, he has trained his precise, unflinching eye on different dimensions of the country, with a focus on social institutions. Again and again, he has returned to the spaces in which human beings organize their lives, charting the great, bright ebb and flow of people and power in offices, schools, cities — all worlds within worlds.

headline: A Cutting-Edge Tactic to Get Out the Vote in 2020: Handwritten Letters
text: The hand-addressed envelope stood out to Bria East, next to the sleek fliers featuring smiling politicians promising criminal justice reform or tax cuts. It had been awhile since anyone had written to Ms. East, 26; the letter, signed only “Maria,” evoked her childhood pen pals.

headline: New York’s School Reopening is Not Proceeding as Planned
text: Shortly after this newsletter was published on Monday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York dropped two bombshells.

headline: Protest Erupts in Poland After New Abortion Ban
text: Tens of thousands of people across Poland have defied Covid-19 restrictions to protest against a new court ruling that imposes a near-total ban on abortion.

headline: One Thing You Can Do: Vote
text: Welcome to the Climate Fwd: newsletter. The New York Times climate team emails readers once a week with stories and insights about climate change. Sign up here to get it in your inbox.

headline: Prepping Your Pet for a Walk Down the Aisle? Hire a Concierge
text: On her way to the wedding at Holiday Acres Christmas Tree Farm in Manvel, Texas, on Nov. 10, 2018, Madison Logan Edwards picked up Ruger, a nine-month-old golden retriever. “I had to pick him up a little early,” she said. “Because of his personality profile, I knew he’d be hyper. So I took him to the dog park and then brushed him out and got him all ready.”

headline: So You Think You Can Run a Dance Cardio Business
text: Anna Kaiser, a celebrity fitness trainer, is known for dispensing advice like “top tips for busy moms who can’t find time to exercise” and for longtime clients like Shakira, whom she trained for the Super Bowl Halftime Show, or Kelly Ripa, whom she guided in a home workout using wine bottles and a dish towel.

headline: People Are Still Having Sex. So Why Are S.T.D. Rates Dropping?
text: For the first time in years, rates of chlamydia, gonorrhea and syphilis, which had been on track in 2020 to hit record highs in the United States, have taken an abrupt downturn.

headline: Business Partner of Giuliani Associate Is Expected to Plead Guilty
text: A business partner of Lev Parnas, who helped Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, dig up dirt on the president’s political rivals, is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to defrauding investors in a start-up, according to two people with knowledge of the case.

headline: It’s Easier to Parent With a Partner in Many Ways, Except This One
text: It’s been almost eight months now, and my daughter and I still don’t have our song. Her older brother, Sam, and I have an album’s worth. I crooned a rotating playlist of off-pitch lullabies — “American Girl,” “Sweet Baby James,” “Me and Bobby McGee” — to him every night for the first two years of his life. But when Eve needs extra help drifting off, I can just hand her off to her dad. This is amazing. And it worries me.

headline: A Biden Win Could Renew a Democratic Split on Trade
text: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign has unified the Democratic Party around a shared goal of ousting President Trump from office. But as the campaign nears an end, a deep split between progressives and moderate Democrats on trade policy is once again spilling out into the open.

headline: Lil Buck Feels the Dancing Spirit All Over Again
text: Lil Buck, the willowy dancer who spins on the toes of his sneakers as if they were point shoes, was a little boy — probably around 6 — when a church choir filled him with such spirit that he got up and began to dance.

headline: Pennsylvania’s top elections official urges voters to drop off absentee ballots in person.
text: Pennsylvania’s top election on Wednesday urged voters who have not yet mailed back their absentee ballots to deliver them to a drop box or county election office rather than rely on the Postal Service, as a court fight over ballot deadlines looms.

headline: We Need Policy, Not WrestleMania
text: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.

headline: U.S. Charges 8 in Plot to Harass Chinese Dissidents
text: The Justice Department announced charges on Wednesday against eight people accused of conspiring to conduct an aggressive harassment campaign on behalf of China to pressure political dissidents and fugitives in the United States to return home to face trial.

headline: ‘City So Real’ Is an Election Story Pulsing With Life
text: Midway through the documentary “City So Real,” Christie Hefner, the former chief executive of Playboy, hosts a “salon dinner” for some Chicago luminaries. With a stunning high-rise view as a backdrop, they talk about their town’s future: whether it will become a gleaming “global city” or descend into “chaos.”

headline: Biden Holds 8-Point Lead in Michigan as He Tries to Reconstruct the ‘Blue Wall’
text: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is leading President Trump by eight percentage points in Michigan, according to a new poll from The New York Times and Siena College on Wednesday, the latest survey to show Mr. Trump’s troubled standing in Midwestern battleground states as white voters without college degrees, his political bulwark, turn away from him.

headline: Review: From Neil LaBute, a Case of He Said, She Said, No One Said
text: NEW PALTZ, N.Y. — If you’d never seen a Neil LaBute play before “True Love Will Find You in the End,” which opened recently at the Denizen Theater here, you might be surprised by the huge twist that comes exactly two-thirds of the way through. I, on the other hand, having seen so many, dreaded the twist the whole time, as if watching an atomic clock count down to a cataclysm.

headline: Disinformation Moves From Social Networks to Texts
text: Last week, a political action committee called the American Principles Project unveiled a new video on Twitter falsely claiming that Democratic presidential nominee Joseph R. Biden Jr. supported sex changes for 8-year-olds.

headline: It’s Biden! No, It’s Trump! Here Are Your Predictions
text: We asked readers for their prophecies, not their wishes. Below is a selection from the more than 500 responses.

headline: Bile and the Beat Fight Heartbreak on Sam Smith’s ‘Love Goes’
text: “Put your hands in the air if you sometimes ever get sad like me,” Sam Smith urges in “So Serious,” one of the triumphantly forlorn songs on their third studio album, “Love Goes.” (Smith’s preferred pronouns are they/their.) Romance is all that matters in Smith’s musical universe. Love is all-important and all-consuming, even — perhaps especially — when it’s going wrong. Obsession prevails, even more than passion.

headline: The 13 Scariest Horror Movies on Netflix Right Now
text: Netflix has done a fine job in recent years of stockpiling horror films — from established classics to newer pictures discovered at international film festivals. But which are the scariest? It’s a pleasure to watch a smart, artful and culturally relevant fright flick. But it’s even better when it spooks you into leaving the lights on after bedtime. Looking to be thoroughly terrorized this Halloween season? Here are 13 devilish films that will have even the most stoic souls jumping at shadows.

headline: Palestinian Leaders Are Banking on Biden Win Next Week
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinians are counting on a Trump defeat next Tuesday. They don’t even want to think about Plan B.

headline: After 12 Years, Arrest Made in Abduction of Former Times Journalist David Rohde
text: Twelve years after a New York Times journalist and two others were taken hostage at gunpoint in Afghanistan and held for more than seven months, an Afghan man has been arrested and charged in the kidnapping, federal authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: K.G.B. Museum Closes; Lipstick Gun and Other Spy Relics Go on Sale
text: Julius Urbaitis had a grand plan: Take his collection of K.G.B. memorabilia, acquired over three decades, and create a museum in Downtown Manhattan. People would come from all over the world to admire Cold War relics like a gun masquerading as a tube of lipstick, a replica of an umbrella with a hidden poison needle and a bronze desk lamp that supposedly sat in Joseph Stalin’s villa.

headline: Biden vowed to ‘deal honestly with the American people’ on the pandemic, and then went to vote.
text: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his wife, Jill, voted by appointment in Delaware on Wednesday, joining more than 70 million Americans who have already cast their ballots.

headline: The New York Store Where Furniture Is Theater
text: In this series for T, the author Reggie Nadelson revisits New York institutions that have defined cool for decades, from time-honored restaurants to unsung dives.

headline: Stocks sink as lawmakers fail to reach agreement on stimulus deal, and coronavirus cases surge.
text: Stocks on Wall Street slid on Wednesday, erasing any remaining gains for October. Traders on Wall Street had already been on edge as the presidential election approaches and lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on what economists say is an essential plan to support businesses and out-of-work Americans.

headline: In Rural Virginia, a Militia Tries to Recruit a New Ally: The County Government
text: HALIFAX, Va. — The board of supervisors meeting in September opened with the familiar liturgy of local government: the prayer, the Pledge of Allegiance, the roll call. The chairman was recognized for completing a course for public officials. “Constitution Week” was hereby proclaimed.

headline: M.T.A. Slashes in Service Could Erase 450,000 Jobs
text: Since the pandemic plunged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority into its worst financial crisis, the agency has warned of doomsday cuts, including slashing service in half and scrapping much-needed infrastructure improvements, that would cripple the region’s public transit network.

headline: Biden’s Caution: Wise Campaign Tactic or Misguided Gamble?
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — On the Friday before Election Day, Joseph R. Biden Jr. will be in the Midwest, campaigning in both Iowa and Wisconsin as he presses his closing argument.

headline: After Backlash, Philip Guston Retrospective to Open in 2022
text: The much-discussed Philip Guston retrospective will now open in 2022, a spokeswoman for the National Gallery of Art in Washington said on Wednesday, after the announcement last month of a delay until 2024 sparked a backlash in the art world.

headline: Virus-Stricken Wisconsin Cancels Nebraska Game
text: The coronavirus pandemic, which has ravaged the Midwest in recent weeks, upended a regional rite — the Big Ten Conference football season — on Wednesday, when No. 9 Wisconsin canceled a game and suspended team activities because of an outbreak in its ranks.

headline: Polish Women Lead Strike Over Abortion Ruling Amid Threats of Crackdown
text: Tens of thousands of women took to the streets in dozens of Polish cities and towns for a nationwide strike on Wednesday to protest a top court’s decision to ban nearly all abortions, even as the nation’s leading politician urged his conservative supporters to “defend Poland.”

headline: 2 Art Gallery Shows to See Right Now
text: Robert Kobayashi (1925-2015) — whose work is the subject of the rigorous yet endearing show “Moe’s Meat Market” — was one of New York’s great outlier artists. He had a brief phase as an Abstract Expressionist, but in the early 1960s devised his own folk-artist version of pointillist painting, packing the signature dots of the style so close together that his textured images seemed solid. How solid? Trees resemble broccoli crowns.

headline: How Memory Maps Fashion’s Future
text: Can you cast your mind back for a moment to spring 2019?

headline: U.S. to Establish Embassy in the Maldives
text: WASHINGTON — The United States will establish an embassy in the Maldives for the first time since the countries opened diplomatic relations in 1966, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said on Wednesday, signifying the archipelago’s growing role in the U.S. strategy to increase America’s presence in the region.

headline: Read the Statement by Miles Taylor
text: Miles Taylor, the former chief of staff at the Department of Homeland Security who was the anonymous author of the New York Times Op-Ed two years ago, released a statement on Wednesday.

headline: Miles Taylor, a Former Homeland Security Official, Reveals He Was ‘Anonymous’
text: WASHINGTON — Miles Taylor, the former chief of staff at the Department of Homeland Security, was the anonymous author of The New York Times Op-Ed article in 2018 whose description of President Trump as “impetuous, adversarial, petty and ineffective” roiled Washington and set off a hunt for his identity, Mr. Taylor confirmed Wednesday.

headline: Biden and Trump will both campaign in Tampa on Thursday, though not at the same time.
text: The city of Tampa will be the center of the presidential election universe on Thursday when President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. visit the crucial battleground state of Florida.

headline: ‘The American People Deserve So Much Better Than This,’ Biden Says
text: On Wednesday, Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Democratic nominee for president, addressed President Trump’s rally he held in Nebraska that left his supporters standing out in the cold for hours.

headline: Utah Jazz to Sell Majority Stake to Tech Entrepreneur
text: Gail Miller, whose family has owned the Utah Jazz for 35 years, has agreed to sell a majority interest in the franchise to Ryan Smith, the co-founder of Qualtrics, a Utah-based software company.

headline: Republicans Blast Social Media C.E.O.s While Democrats Deride Hearing
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers hammered the chief executives of Twitter, Facebook, Google and one another at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, with Republicans claiming the companies were suppressing conservative views while Democrats accused their colleagues of holding a “sham” hearing for political gain.

headline: Listen to Soundscapes from Home
text: Welcome. I wrote a few weeks ago about the sounds of pigeons undertaking their vigorous morning drills, their wings slapping against my windows. It’s easy, when we’re caught up in a day’s worth of doing and getting done, to ignore the soundtrack that’s always accompanying us, whether furnished by nature or by civilization.

headline: Modern Love Podcast: Devoted but Doomed
text: In college, Malcolm Conner penned a rambling email intended for his crush. “You have cow eyes,” he wrote. “I know that sounds like a bad thing but have you ever looked into a cow’s eyes? They are so deep and brown and beautiful.”

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: President Emmanuel Macron announced on Wednesday that France would go into a second national lockdown starting on Friday and lasting one month. Most schools will remain open and visits in retirement homes will remain possible. Otherwise, people may not leave their homes other than for essential reasons.

headline: Statins May Have Cancer Benefits
text: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs don’t just lower the risk of heart attacks. They may also help some cancer patients live longer.

headline: Cecilia Chiang, Who Brought Authentic Chinese Food to America, Dies at 100
text: Cecilia Chiang, whose San Francisco restaurant, the Mandarin, introduced American diners in the 1960s to the richness and variety of authentic Chinese cuisine, died on Wednesday at her home in San Francisco. She was 100.

headline: Ford and Fiat Chrysler report strong profits as car sales rebound.
text: Ford Motor reported a big jump in profit in the third quarter after a yearslong restructuring and a rebound in sales after the pandemic shut down dealerships and factories for about two months this spring.

headline: Officer Who Pressed a Knee Into Bystander’s Neck Leaves N.Y.P.D.
text: A New York City police officer facing misconduct charges for kneeling on a bystander’s neck during a social-distancing arrest has retired, according to the victim’s lawyer and the officer’s labor union.

headline: Black Women’s Hair and Horror Movies: What Could Go Wrong?
text: Halfway through “Bad Hair,” Justin Simien’s horror-comedy on Hulu, a group of Black women sit in a conference room and debate the merits of changing their hairstyles to conform to the new corporate climate at Culture, the Black music television network where they work.

headline: Oklahoma Ice Storms Leave Thousands Without Power on Eve of Early Voting
text: Hundreds of thousands in Oklahoma are still without power on Wednesday after powerful ice storms downed electrical lines across the state on Monday, creating hazardous conditions the day before in-person early voting is set to begin in the state.

headline: Juan Torruella, Groundbreaking U.S. Appeals Judge, Dies at 87
text: Juan R. Torruella, a groundbreaking Hispanic federal judge in New England who championed the rights of his fellow Puerto Ricans and, in a recent case, joined a decision to overturn the death penalty imposed on a Boston Marathon bomber, died on Monday in San Juan. He was 87.

headline: At Arizona rally, Trump says the country is ‘rounding the turn,’ despite a record number of virus cases.
text: Rallying supporters in Bullhead City, Ariz., the first of two stops in the state on Wednesday, President Trump claimed that a vaccine for the coronavirus would be available “momentarily,” speeding up an already exaggerated timeline in the final days of the presidential race.

headline: In Azerbaijan, a String of Explosions, Screams and Then Blood
text: BARDA, Azerbaijan — The first explosion was loud enough to make us stop the car. It seemed close and sounded like a rocket, so we quickly jumped out and crouched down by a wall.

headline: France and Germany Lock Down as Second Coronavirus Wave Grows
text: BRUSSELS — France announced a second nationwide lockdown and Germany moved to the very edge of one on Wednesday, testing their pandemic-weary populations as they tried to stop a mounting new wave of coronavirus infections from swamping hospitals and undoing hopes of economic recovery.

headline: France imposes a new nationwide lockdown, and braces for fresh economic pain.
text: France was bracing for a fresh blow to its beleaguered economy as President Emmanuel Macron reimposed a nationwide lockdown through December to prevent an alarming surge of coronavirus cases from spiraling out of control.

headline: ‘I Am a Proud Patriotic American,’ Harris Says at Rally
text: Senator Kamala Harris, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, campaigned in Tucson, Ariz., Wednesday, and criticized the White House’s handling of the coronavirus and pushed back on Republicans saying she is pressing a “socialist” agenda.

headline: After a Dampened Celebration, Enduring Glory Still Awaits the Dodgers
text: ARLINGTON, Texas — At the very end, 2020 did what it does best, intruding on joy with an unwelcome risk-or-reward calculation. Justin Turner, part of the soul of the Los Angeles Dodgers, learned that he had tested positive for the coronavirus during the World Series clincher on Tuesday night at Globe Life Field. Then he defied orders from Major League Baseball security and celebrated on the field with teammates and family members, at times without wearing a mask.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: Europe has tried for weeks to slow the spread of the virus with targeted restrictions instead of the unpopular nationwide lockdowns that were imposed in the spring. But as a furious second wave pushes hospitalizations, deaths and cases to levels not seen since the beginning of the pandemic, countries have begun to change course.

headline: What Are You Seeing at the Polls?
text: Do you have a tip about voting problems? The New York Times is partnering with ProPublica and hundreds of other news organizations to track voting impediments and other challenges to the reliability and integrity of the election. Submit your tips here.

headline: Diane di Prima, Poet of the Beat Era and Beyond, Dies at 86
text: Diane di Prima, the most prominent woman among the male-dominated Beat poets, who after being immersed in the bohemian swirl of Greenwich Village in the 1950s moved to the West Coast and continued to publish prolifically in a wide range of forms, died on Sunday in San Francisco. She was 86.

headline: Covid Relief for Nonprofits
text: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Allows Longer Deadlines for Absentee Ballots in Pennsylvania and North Carolina
text: WASHINGTON — In a pair of decisions welcomed by Democrats, the Supreme Court on Wednesday let election officials in two key battleground states, Pennsylvania and North Carolina, accept absentee ballots for several days after Election Day.

headline: After 50 Years, a Suspect Emerges in a Cold Murder Case
text: Rosalie Sanz was a teenager in 1969 when she looked out the window of her family’s San Diego home on a dark November night and saw two men in suits. She remembers her mother listening quietly to the detectives telling her that her 23-year-old daughter, Mary Scott, had been murdered.

headline: The 2020 Campaign Is the Most Expensive Ever (By a Lot)
text: The 2020 election has blown past previous records to become the most expensive campaign in American history, with the final tally for the battle for the White House and control of the Senate and the House expected to hit nearly $14 billion, according to new projections made by the Center for Responsive Politics.

headline: The Supreme Court allows longer absentee ballot deadlines in Pennsylvania and North Carolina.
text: In a pair of decisions welcomed by Democrats, the Supreme Court on Wednesday at least temporarily let election officials in two key battleground states, Pennsylvania and North Carolina, accept absentee ballots for several days after Election Day.

headline: Stocks Post Worst Day in 4 Months as Infections Rise Around the Globe
text: Coronavirus flare-ups across the United States and new lockdown measures in major European economies sent stocks sliding to their worst performance in months on Wednesday.

headline: The Best of the Kennedys?
text: CATCHING THE WINDEdward Kennedy and the Liberal HourBy Neal Gabler

headline: Europe, 2020 Election, Dodgers: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Finally, the Resistance Gets to Vote
text: We are now entering the homestretch. Voters will finally have a say in whether Donald Trump’s reign of terror and idiocy continues or ends.

headline: Say Yes to Progressive Taxation
text: Most Americans accept the common-sense case for progressive taxation: Those who have more ought to contribute more to the society that is the foundation of their prosperity.

headline: Trump claims the nation is ‘rounding the turn’ on the virus as cases climb; Biden vows to ‘deal honestly with the American people.’
text: The coronavirus pandemic — which has reshaped the presidential race by transforming the conventions, the debates, the way the candidates campaign and how voters cast their ballots — dominated the race on Wednesday as President Trump and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. held fast to the diametrically opposed positions they have staked out.

headline: Wedding and Birthday Party Infect 56, Leaving Nearly 300 in Quarantine
text: Long Island health officials scrambled to contain a coronavirus outbreak in Suffolk County when dozens of people tested positive for the virus after attending a high-end Sweet 16 party in September that violated state restrictions on gatherings.

headline: Baltimore Museum of Art Cancels Painting Sale that Drew Complaints
text: The Baltimore Museum of Art is pausing its plan to sell three major paintings from its collection. A Sotheby’s sale of works by Brice Marden, Clyfford Still and Andy Warhol was estimated to bring in $65 million to fund acquisitions of art by people of color and staff-wide salary increases.

headline: Cuba Says U.S. Restrictions Will Force Western Union Offices to Close
text: MEXICO CITY — In the face of widening American financial restrictions on Cuba, more than 400 Western Union offices on the island will close, Cuban authorities said, a move that could severely restrict the flow of remittances from abroad and worsen a profound economic crisis that has led to widespread food shortages on the island.

headline: Days From Election, Police Killing of Black Man Roils Philadelphia
text: PHILADELPHIA — There is a grim familiarity to it all. In the final days of a bitter election, it is a reprise of the terrible images that the country has come to know all too well this year: The shaky cellphone video, the abrupt death of a Black man at the hands of the police. The howls of grief at the scene. The protests that formed immediately. The looting of stores that lasted late into the night.

headline: M.L.B. Says Justin Turner Refused to Stay Off Field After Dodgers’ Win
text: The joy of the Dodgers’ long coveted World Series title was overshadowed on Tuesday night when Justin Turner, the team’s veteran third baseman, joined his teammates in celebration on the field shortly after learning he had tested positive for the coronavirus.

headline: Er, Can I Ask a Few Questions About Abortion?
text: Millions of American Christians are likely to vote for President Trump on Tuesday because they believe it a religious obligation to support a president who will appoint “pro-life” judges.

headline: Trump’s Closing Argument on Virus Clashes With Science, and Voters’ Lives
text: As an immense new surge in coronavirus cases sweeps the country, President Trump is closing his re-election campaign by pleading with voters to ignore the evidence of a calamity unfolding before their eyes and trust his word that the disease is already disappearing as a threat to their personal health and economic well being.

headline: Into the Unknown
text: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Court Rejects Appeal of Guantánamo Convict Who Rejoined Al Qaeda
text: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
